text: What is an easy way to create a trivial one-off Python object?
I would like to create a trivial one-off Python object to hold some command-line options.
I would like to do something like this:

code:
options = ??????
options.VERBOSE = True
options.IGNORE_WARNINGS = False

# Then, elsewhere in the code...
if options.VERBOSE:
    ...

text: Of course I could use a dictionary, but options.VERBOSE is more readable and easier to type than options['VERBOSE'].
I thought that I should be able to do
, since object is the base type of all class objects and therefore should be something like a class with no attributes.
But it doesn't work, because an object created using object() doesn't have a __dict__ member, and so one cannot add attributes to it:

code:
options.VERBOSE = True
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: 'object' object has no attribute 'VERBOSE'

text: What is the simplest "pythonic" way to create an object that can be used this way, preferably without having to create an extra helper class?
